questions.text: The gap between a user's goal and the system's ability to help achieve it is known in HCI as:
questions.explanation: The Gulf of Execution measures the difficulty the user has in performing a task using the interface provided.

questions.text: According to the Berry-Picking model, the Information Access Process is:
questions.explanation: Berry-picking acknowledges that information needs change as users discover new keywords and documents.

questions.text: A 'Starting Point' where the user explores categories rather than typing words is called:
questions.explanation: Browsing is preferred when the user has low intent or isn't sure of the exact terminology.

questions.text: Which type of feedback involves the system observing clicks and dwell time without asking the user?
questions.explanation: Implicit feedback is gathered automatically based on user behavioral patterns.

questions.text: KWIC (Key Word In Context) is an interface support feature that shows:
options: Only the title of the page
A snippet of text surrounding the search keywords
A list of synonyms for the query
questions.explanation: KWIC helps users evaluate relevance quickly without opening the full document.
questions.topic: Interface Support for the Search Process

questions.text: What is the primary goal of Faceted Search interfaces?
options: To speed up the computer's CPU
To allow multi-dimensional filtering of results (e.g. by price, color, brand)
To replace the search box entirely
questions.explanation: Facets provide structured ways to narrow down result sets.

questions.text: What is a major research trend in IR interfaces?
options: Removing all images from web results
questions.explanation: Conversational search (LLMs/Agents) is current state-of-the-art research.
